title: but that panned out OK for Sir Alex Ferguson
text:

A fanbase divided over the manager, a squad full of players who often didn't convince, and a envious glance towards their rivals from Liverpool at the top of the table.

The 1989/90 season didn't start well for Manchester United .

Alex Ferguson's side - he wouldn't have liked the idea of a knighthood back then - began the campaign with four defeats from their seven Division One games, and by the time of a goalless draw with Sheffield Wednesday in their eighth they were 17th in the table, one place above the relegation zone.

The storm clouds were gathering over the Scot, who had remained trophyless during his almost three years as manager.

(Image: Daily Mirror)

They would eventually lift dramatically, although not permanently as United fans are now finding out.

Now Ole Gunnar Solskjaer isn't going to turn into Ferguson, we can all be pretty sure of that and however much he wants to.

The Norwegian took the Red Devils into the weekend in 10th place with just nine points from their seven games, not quite as bad as 1989/90 but on the way.

(Image: Daily Mirror)

But the club's current predicament will remind some fans of that beginning 30 years ago, with the season ultimately ending in one of Ferguson's most valued triumphs.

Amid the exciting but ultimately flawed attempt to buy the club by businessman Michael Knighton, United plodded along as Ferguson's wildly inconsistent side struggled for goals and shipped far too many.

A run of four wins from five games in October and November 1989, and then crucially four straight wins in March and April 1990 - each featuring a goal from striker Mark Robins - were effectively what kept United up.

(Image: Allsport)

They ultimately ended up in 13th, five points clear of relegation and sandwiched in between the Cities of Coventry and Manchester.

It was in the FA Cup where the real memories were made though.

Nottingham Forest, Hereford United, Newcastle United and Sheffield United were all beaten by one goal on United's route to the semi-finals, where Oldham Athletic were the opposition at Manchester City's Maine Road.

(Image: Getty Images)

A thrilling 3-3 draw after extra-time meant that a replay was needed, and it was there that Robins scored the 114th minute winner that famously saved a struggling Ferguson his job.

Crystal Palace were faced in the final, Mark Hughes and Ian Wright each scored twice in a 3-3 draw at Wembley, before unsung hero left-back Lee Martin popped up with the winner in the replay five days later.

Ferguson finally got his hand on a trophy at United, and he wouldn't stop there.
description: The Red Devils have taken just nine points from seven games this season, evoking memories of the 1989/90 campaign
